ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Loved this class. Very useful. Just what I needed this semester - fit well with other things I was doing.
It is very freeing to be able to write about anything and make yourself vulnerable to you peers critique.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I loved getting to write every week, to get personal feedback from Verlyn, and to discuss my writing during office hours. That was certainly the best part of the course. Class time went well, I liked analyzing sentences and workshopping students' pieces. Like most writing courses I've taken here, the learning really happened out of class, when I was writing and getting comments from the professor.
Clear writing is important to most professions, and this is a great crash course on how to do it. Writing something each week, and reading and dissecting each other's work was very helpful.
The course operated like a writing workshop and the time spent dissecting student pieces was extremely valuable. I would suggest longer required readings each week.
Freedom to write. Great feedback. Good discussion. Revolutionary. I wish everyone had to take this course. The world would be a much clearer place.
Verlyn's one-on-one office hours. He took the time to go over your recent piece and talk about how you can improve your prose in a way that was relevant and useful to your area of focus.
Personal feedback on writing from Verlyn
Freedom of expression
Constant and very attentive feedback.
Submitting weekly writings.

We have been so luck to get in-depth and meaningful feedback from someone of Professor Klinkenborg's experience and caliber. His approach is critical while still being motivating and uplifting, which is so hard to effectively pull off.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I think it would have been nice to do small group work in class, to get to diagnose and then fix sentences individually or in groups before we did it as a class. It was a bit too easy to let other people diagnose the problems, and not get the practice of really doing it for myself.
As difficult as it is to turn people away, I think this course would benefit from a smaller enrollment.

I could never tell this to Verlyn for some reason. But when you do the "some sentences' I wish you would pause before going on after each one in case anyone has a question about the advice you gave. On this note, you must not have seemed approachable enough for me to say this in person...but you were pretty approachable. So now I am confused. But maybe I'm just tired. And jet lagged.
Verlyn's handwriting is very hard to read!
Sometimes it was unclear why good writing was good
Meeting times

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: It was very effective. We as writers shared in detail how we felt while writing our weekly pieces.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: The one class that has taught me how to write well and challenge the jargon and semi-colons expected of academic writing.
We all write. Most of write a lot. This will help with literally everything I do that involves writing. That's huge.
Communicating science is an essential skill that most scientists struggle with. This course helped to clarify how I can improve my science writing in order to communicate it with the public.
This course was a good writing workshop. It forced me to write consistently and think consciously about my sentences.
I aim to write articles and books in future. So this was one of the most essential courses for me.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To improve my writing.
To be a better critical reader and writer.
To improve writing skills on a sentence-by-sentence level.
To become a better writer.
I wanted to improve my skills as a writer.
See Question 17. Also I had heard great things about Verlyn's teaching style and the course overall.
I wanted to learn writing with a master of the craft.
I aim to write articles and books in future. So this was one of the most essential courses for me.
To improve my writing, revising, and editing.
I wanted more writing experience, and I hoped to develop a higher comfort level with the writing process. Professor Klinkenborg was the perfect person to help with these things.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes and beyond!
Yup, I became a better writer and I feel like I have the tools and motivation to keep getting better.
Yes!
Yes, I was satisfied with what I learned in the course.
More than met my expectations!!! Thanks V!
What I gained exceeded my expectations.
Yes. And I hope to continue my learning even after the course is over.
Yes!
Yes. It was a subtle transformation of my writing skill.
Exceeded my expectations.
Yep! We came away from the class with useful, concrete things to watch for in our writing, but each week's feedback also helped make clear some of the more difficult and ethereal aspects of writing.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you'd like to work on your writing, definitely take it. You write 2 pages a week, read fantastic writing, and get to work with Verlyn, who is a sharp editor and delightful editor. If you're looking to write longer form pieces this isn't the course for you, as should be obvious. I'd say take it by all means.
Take it! Everyone should take this course. (Although that contradicts what I said about having a smaller enrollment...)

This course is less structure than other writing courses at FES. If students have a clear idea of what they want to focus on writing each week, there is much to be gained. If students are unsure what the want to improve, they may feel lost in the course.

Take it. I guess it can be hard to apply this to say...an MESC thesis, but I wasn't do that, so I didnt care. But this course would be positively useful for everyone. Please take it, your readers will be grateful.
This is an extremely valuable course. I highly recommend it.

You get as much out of the course as you put into it. It's easy to put assignments off and then just scramble to write something quickly - but you won't benefit from that because you're not putting in the effort to improve your writing. Take Verlyn's comments to heart and really practice doing what he suggests. He's very helpful and understanding.

If you want to be forced to write frequently, and have your writing edited by a master craftsman, take this course! The class is designed to turn people accustomed to writing academic prose into creative writers. If you are already a creative writer, the class can still be helpful, but won't necessarily be as challenging or thought-provoking.
Experiment with different areas of your interest when you submit your pieces each week.
Have fun writing.
Don't be nervous about other people reading your writing. Everyone will mirror Professor Klinkenborg's supportive, while still constructively critical, attitude.
